This follows on from the recent announcement
that Darwall is to hand over the two mutual funds he currently manages to Mark Nichols (and now also Mark Heslop). Darwall has agreed a non-compete in the UCITS market for the 2 years following his departure. Darwall for the time being remains the manager on the JEO investment trust, but we suspect it is likely that the JEO board will follow Darwall to his new company in due course, subject to regulatory consents being provided and an appropriate notice period being served.

BE11:19am

We calculate that JEO currently contributes £968m to group AuM (2% of total), £7.3m to management fees (2% of total) and £5.1m contribution to PBT assuming a 70% contribution margin (3% of total). JEO is also one of Jupiter's most notable performance fee contributors - we estimate £7m in FY19 for example. For modeling purposes, we assume that Jupiter loses the mandate in Q320, after allowing time to set up the new entity, get regulatory approval and board approval. We calculate that the two mutual funds contribute £8.2bn to group AuM (18%), £74m (19%) to revenue and £52m (31%) contribution to PBT. For the time being we assume no incremental changes to our flow forecasts, since this in a sense is not "new news" for the mutual funds and there is a 2 year non-compete agreement in place. Clearly though, we will continue to monitor the flows carefully given the clear importance of these two funds to the group.

In summary, this is evidently not helpful news for the group. We repeat our recent comment that the "flow situation remains finely balanced." We note that there are several mitigating factors taken (such as the orderly handover of the UCITS funds and the 2 year non-compete) which should help limit any immediate impact.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We Think There's a Real Risk of Other Jupiter PMs Following Mr. Darwall Jupiter has a unique culture where portfolio managers are able to operate in a highly autonomous manner with minimal bureaucracy. We believe a number of Jupiter's PMs joined the firm from larger asset managers for these very reasons. However, with a new CEO, CFO and Head of Distribution and a push to grow an institutional multi-asset product (which will require greater collaboration amongst PMs), these culture impacting changes increase the risk of other PM departures, in our view. Given JUP's high key-man risk, we believe this skews the company's risk/reward profile negatively.

We continue to rate Jupiter a Sell. At 15x 2020 UBSe, Jupiter's valuation is implying inflows of ~10% per annum and the shares are trading in the upper end of peer valuation despite seeing outflows in 5 of the past 6 months and a key PM departing.

The trust had £975m of net assets at 28 June, and pays a quarterly management fee of 0.75% of net assets. This is equivalent to £7.3m of annual fee revenue for JUP, 2% of our forecast of £371.7m of 2020 net management fees.
Clearly, this is negative news, and if the directors do decide to change adviser and Devon receives the necessary regulatory approvals, we would expect the decision to take effect by the end of the year and therefore reduce JUP's 2020e net management fees by c. 2%. Clients of the mutual funds Mr Darwall runs (c. £7.9bn of AUM) could be swayed by the JEO board's decision, ditto segregated mandates clients.

BE11:27am

We downgrade to Buy from Neutral. The shares are now close to our revised PT of 5500p (5300p) and the 2019E PE of 26x and FCF yield of 3% look fair valuation metrics in the context of Croda's portfolio (75% of group EBIT comprising Consumer and Life Science actives and 25% industrial-facing products) and peer valuations. In addition there are, potentially, some headwinds for 1H19 (results due July 24th), such that for 2019 we now rely, less comfortably, on 2H growth than previously: 3%/8% EPS growth for 1H/2H against previously 6%/5%. We increase our 2019/20 EPS estimates by 1%/3% on FX but reduce our organic sales for 2019 (-40 bps). We are 2% below cons EPS for 2019.

BE11:27am

This is UBS, to be clear.

Bluesky21 Thanks re Croda, BE!
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Personal Care comps have been a challenge for 2019 since the trajectory from 2018 became clear in February (1H organic sales +9%, 2H +4%) and, in addition, recent data from our European HPC team suggests evidence of a material slowdown in the US cosmetics market. Additionally, there are two other issues to consider for the s-term EPS growth trajectory: 1) Croda's crop care business could see some adverse fall-out from US weather disruption; 2) the US bio-surfactants plant has not restarted and, whilst idle, losses are accruing to the tune of £2m per quarter (3% to EPS on an annualised basis). We now model start-up in 4Q19, previously mid-year.

We also lower 2020E £0.10 to £2.05.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Funding Circle have, alongside reporting their 1H19 trading update, meaningfully downgraded their full year expectations for the business, due to a worsening in the demand environment for loans and having to tighten their lending criteria to protect investor returns. FY19 revenue guidance has been downgraded from an implied greater than 41% growth to ~20%, a halving of the growth rate. With ~30% growth reported for H1, this of course implies an even steeper reduction in the growth rate for 2H19 y/y (to ~12%). Another way to look at this update from a revenue perspective, is that revenue looks to have only grown ~4% sequentially in 1H18, with the new guidance implying ~8% sequential growth into H2.

1966AndAllThat @Tom key I think is AMD was forced to go fabless. Intel didn't bother updating their fabs as increasingly expensive and unnecessary as they did not compete in mobile phone chips (that need the latest chips for good battery life). AMD now a generation ahead as use TSMC fabs off peak when TSMC not making iPhone chips.
BE11:42am

It also guides to an adjusted EBITDA loss margin for 2019 now better than last year. Last year the company achieved a EBITDA margin of -20% and on a post IFRS 16 basis this equates to ~16.5% loss, implying the company is targeting to beat the margin on this basis. The previous guidance was looking loss for perhaps 6.5%-7.5% or an EBITDA loss of £13-15m including the impact of IFRS 16 and new products initiatives. The 20% revenue growth guidance implies ~£170m of revenues or a £30m reduction in revenues. Were the company not to reduce planned cost, this would imply an EBITDA loss of £43-45m or a margin of ~25-26%. It will therefore need to curtail spending significantly to get there. We expect cost controls to focus on reducing marketing spend as the remaining costs such as employees are largely a fixed cost. This also implies a meaningful improvement in H2 sequentially, leaving some risk to this profitability guidance.

All this will raise very difficult questions for the company around the exit rate of the business and its ability to retain its medium-term financial plan. A lot will depend on whether Funding Circle has had to dramatically tighten its lending criteria to protect investors, and therefore once it has readjusted its models can reaccelerate growth, or whether demand has simply deteriorated to such an extent that there is little the company can do to reaccelerate in the near-term. Investors will also ask the extent to which any tightening in supply has affected Funding Circle’s ability to lend; withdrawal times for investors on the platform have been significantly lengthening and the listed SME investment vehicle is winding up, as previously reported. Speaking to the company, however, it appears that this is fully a demand issue.

The shares have clearly been very weak over the past weeks and months and therefore one can argue that today’s update is, to a certain extent, in the price. However, with Funding Circle currently in the loss-making stage of its development, and therefore with very little valuation support, a lot will depend simply on the willingness of investors to support the business through the near-term disruption. The stock currently trades at 3.3x FY19 revenue (based on the new guidance) and we are Equal Weight.

Revenue has rebounded in Q2 to c$94m but remains below both our and consensus run-rate. No changes to our numbers with the expectation that lower marketing costs negate a reduction in revenue. Whilst shares trade on a low valuation c6x, there remains a high level of earnings uncertainty and we maintain our Reduce recommendation.

red q2 better cos nice drop in stockmarkets near start. watch bitcoin for q3...
BE11:53am

Reviewing our forecasts, we find that our profit estimate for FY19 is some 12% below consensus. We make no changes, and continue to forecast PBT/EPS of $162.8m/111.5c (consensus: $184.5m/122c), with the reduction in revenue likely to be offset by lower marketing costs. The company has stated that overall performance is trading in line with expectations.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

hilst shares trade on a low valuation of c6x, there remains a high level of earnings uncertainty. If for example, core trading continued in a similar vein as Q1, we estimate that earnings could be 31% lower and this would mean the multiple would be closer to 10x. We would not dispute that if certain things go in Plus500’s favour the business model can deliver high operating margins and significant amounts of cash. Against that, we currently do not have much confidence in our forecasts, whether a function of falling client numbers or the continuing impact of regulation. At this stage, we expect Plus500 to remain an investment solely for those with a high risk appetite.

CountryBoy Following up Fridays discussion on Costain. Trying to rally today on the Capital Markets day. Investor relations got the bad news out ahead of the new CEO's strategy presentation today. Not sure if I'm brave enough to knife catch in this sector at the moment.
BE11:54am

Of if you prefer, Liberum has a £10 target and an asterisk next to the name to identify itself as house broker.

BE11:54am

Forget the forecasts - Plus500 just earned 25p a share, with our existing costs assumptions, in Q2, and it was not a high volatility quarter, containing as it did April, the lowest activity month of the year so far. More than that, the update indicates that a higher number of new customers just arrived while their average cost has declined as the competition invests less in new client acquisition. We believe this would argue for higher revenues, all being equal, in H2, as indeed we have forecast. The company indicates it is trading in line with current market expectations. Q2 revenues were however 6% light on our own forecast, so we pull 2019 revenues down 6%, meaning EPS in GBP down 8% on the number we published after Q1. Price target is unchanged because it is only 10x what this company just earned in Q2 (annualised). 10% dividend yield, 19% FCF yield and 43% of mkt cap. in net cash.

BE11:57am

Although the performance was better than the market had feared, we await more detail on profitability in the full interim results and so reiterate our Hold recommendation.

BE11:57am

Gross revenues appear to be stabilising: In Q1, Plus500 earned gross
revenue of $82m. In Q2, despite a fall in volatility and rising markets,
Plus500 was able to grow gross revenue by 13% to $93m. This means that
since the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) restrictions
were introduced in August 2018, Plus500 has reported average gross
revenues of $92m per quarter (Berenberg estimate for Q3 2018, all other
periods as reported by the company– Q3 2018: $94m, Q4 2018: $99m, Q1
2019: $82m). For the first half of the year therefore, Plus500 reported gross
revenues of $175m, ahead of our estimate of $171m.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Market P&L affected Q1 significantly, far smaller contribution in Q2: In
Q1, although Plus500 generated gross revenue of $82m, it also incurred
market losses of $28m, ie 34% of gross revenue. This reduced net revenue
to $54m, which was a 65% sequential drop. In Q2, market P&L played a far
smaller role and contributed a positive of only $1m, giving net revenue of
$94m. Therefore, in H1 Plus500’s net revenue was $148m. It also implies
average net revenue of $102m per quarter since the ESMA rules were
introduced. Assuming $102m per quarter for the rest of 2019 implies a full
year net revenue figure of c$352m, which falls within the margin for error
of our current estimate of $358m.

full interim results. These will be released in August, but no precise date
has been set.
● Valuation: Plus500 is trading on (rolling 12-month forward consensus)
4.7x earnings, which compares to the five year average multiple of 7.6x.

No certainty, blah blah. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE12:01pm

The headline valuation at $4bn is equivalent to c£3.2bn, in line with market consensus expectations of c£3-3.5bn for the asset. WPP has previously stated that it will retain between 25% and 40% of Kantar. On the basis of (i) no debt within Kantar and a sale price of £3.2bn, (ii) the sale of a 60% stake would raise £1.92bn. (iii) If Kantar were levered up to 3.5x ND/E this would provide WPP with a further dividend of c£500m and total net proceeds of c£2.4bn. (iv) WPP has pledged to return c50% to shareholders or c£1.2bn. (v) Assuming a buyback at c£10 per share, we estimate that annual EPS dilution would be in the order of 5% and that (vi) net debt/EBITDA post the deal would fall to c1.5x, meaning WPP would fulfil its target to move ND/E in the 1.5-1.75x range.Overall this is much as expected, but will still be regarded as a positive result, we believe, restoring WPP’s balance sheet with an acceptable level of EPS dilution while removing a business that has consistently underperformed the rest of WPP in terms of organic revenue growth. Beyond the Kantar sale, the next event is WPP’s Q2 results due in August. We look for -3% Q2 organic revenue growth (slightly worse than the -2.8% of Q1) with North America at -7.5%. We look for a c160bps reduction YoY in the H1 margin reflecting the weak top line, the relatively high profitability of the US and the weighting of cost savings to H2. WPP also announced on Monday the sale of its minority shareholding in Chime Group Holdings Limited to the majority shareholder Providence for £54.4m and potential additional amounts based on the future value of Chime.The disposal is in line with WPP’s new strategy as set out in December 2018, a key element of which is to focus on its main areas of business and simplify its operations through the disposal of non-core assets.
